4.56.text: These people are amongst the greatest quiz players in Britain.

9.92.text: Together they make up the Eggheads,

11.92.text: arguably the most formidable quiz team in the country.

17.28.text: The question is, can they be beaten?

23.72.text: Welcome to Eggheads, the show where a team of five quiz Challengers

27.24.text: pit their wits against possibly the greatest quiz team in Britain.

33.24.text: Taking on the awesome might of our quiz goliaths

36.20.text: are The Old Contemptibles from Huddersfield.

39.28.text: Now, everyone on this team is part of the Colne Valley Quiz League.

44.48.text: Hello, my name is Jimmy, I'm retired,

47.44.text: I was a subcontractor in the construction industry.

51.08.text: Hello, I'm David. Before I retired, I was a chartered accountant.

55.24.text: Hi, my name is Alistair, I manage a newsagent's shop.

59.16.text: Hi, I'm Jeremy and I'm a local government finance officer.

62.52.text: Hello, I'm Kay, I'm a legal officer for a local authority.

66.28.text: So, team, Jimmy, welcome and just tell us

69.84.text: why the name The Old Contemptibles? I know it's an important name.

73.32.text: Well, it was during the First World War

76.12.text: and my grandfather's regiment - unfortunately they got decimated

79.80.text: along with the Canadians and they were co-opted onto other regiments.

83.92.text:
- In his case, so I believe, it was the Lancashire Fusiliers... 
- Yeah.

92.44.text: they were the firing single-shot rifles at the Germans so fast,

96.12.text: the Germans thought they were being machine-gunned,

103.16.text: "Rid me of this contemptible little army."

106.96.text: They weren't able to do it.

109.32.text: And they took that as a compliment, not as an insult.

114.12.text: Hence, they got the nickname The Old Contemptibles.

118.12.text:
- That was my grandfather, yes. 
- If we said Old Contemptibles to

120.96.text: you, Chris, you'd be straight there, wouldn't you?

124.00.text: Veterans of the professional army of 1914, yeah.

126.80.text: Armed with the finest infantry weapon ever made,

131.68.text: And in the hands of a professional soldier, that was one deadly weapon.

134.76.text: And the Germans didn't like it up 'em, sir.

139.12.text: And the name came from the Kaiser. I didn't realise that.

141.56.text: Yeah, he referred, "Oh England's contemptible little army."

144.20.text: And they took a perverse pride in that -

148.28.text: OK, so you are now playing The Old Contemptibles here

151.24.text: and Jimmy and team. And, Alistair, the team captain,

153.72.text: you brought them together, is that right?

155.80.text: Yes. I'm more a middle-aged Contemptible, I think.

158.32.text: LAUGHTER Well, let's see how you go.

161.32.text: Every day there is £1,000-worth of cash up for grabs

163.64.text: for our Challengers. However, if they fail to defeat the Eggheads,

166.88.text: the prize money rolls over to the next show.

169.48.text: So, Old Contemptibles, the Eggheads have won the last 16 games,

173.24.text: so they are ripe and ready here for a bashing at some point, aren't you?

176.72.text: Let's face it. It's going to happen.

178.28.text: £17,000 for you to win, shall we start?

181.28.text:
- Yep. 
- OK, I thought you were going to say no for a second.

185.28.text: I wouldn't know what to do.

186.88.text: The first head-to-head battle is on the subject of Arts & Books.

192.52.text:
- Kay, I think. 
- I think, Kay.

194.44.text: Kay, all right. Against which Egghead?

204.96.text: That's pretty clear. So it's going to be Kay on Arts & Books.

207.60.text: You've had this quite a lot, Barry.

209.24.text: I think people look at you and think you don't read much.

211.68.text: They'd be surprised then, wouldn't they?

214.40.text: Well, I know they would, but anyway. We shall see.

216.80.text: Old Contemptibles versus the Eggheads, let's start.

219.72.text: Please go to the Question Room now.

223.16.text:
- I gather it's your wedding anniversary, Kay. 
- Yes, 31 years.

226.84.text: I think we need a round of applause, don't we?

229.44.text: Cos you're married to Jeremy, here,

231.76.text: so is it good being married to a Jeremy?...

235.80.text: Good. I'm pleased to hear it.

237.56.text:
- So you're on Arts & Books - do you do a lot of reading? 
- Yes.

242.64.text: And you read stuff from now, or yesterday?

246.64.text: I tend to read fiction, but I do read some non-fiction.

249.76.text: I read well over 100 books a year.

252.36.text: Oh, really, where do you get time to do that?

255.00.text: I commute, so I spend a lot of time reading.

257.76.text: All right, well, 100 books a year, I bet even you can't beat that,

260.80.text:
- Barry? 
- I could have when I was younger, but maybe not now.

263.96.text: OK. Kay, I'm looking forward to this, do you to go first or second?

273.68.text: In which decade did Andy Warhol

275.28.text: create his 32 Campbell's Soup Cans paintings?

282.96.text: I think he's most associated with the 1960s,

287.80.text: You're spot-on, well done. '60s it was. Over to you, Barry...

292.52.text: In the Jungle Book by Rudyard Kipling,

294.96.text: which of these characters is a tiger?

300.84.text: It has a wonderful name. Baloo is a bear,

303.44.text: and Kaa is a snake but the tiger was indisputably Shere Khan.

307.24.text: Shere Khan is right. The tiger.

311.00.text: Kay, the Iliad is an epic poem

314.36.text: believed to have been written by which of these authors?

320.96.text: It was thought to have been written by Homer.

326.16.text: Barry, A Feast For Crows is the fourth

328.32.text: in a series of books by which author?

336.92.text: This is the Game Of Thrones question, isn't it?

341.48.text: It is indeed George RR Martin.

345.36.text: Back to you, Kay, keep the pressure on this Egghead,

347.76.text: he can crack more easily than you might think.

350.00.text: Which famous Russian novel starts with the sentence,

355.00.text: "each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way?"

364.88.text: Right... I've not read Dr Zhivago.

367.60.text: I don't think The Brothers Karamazov starts like that,

374.32.text: Your husband is nodding, you'll pleased to know.

376.60.text: Anna Karenina is the right answer.

378.56.text: Jeremy's given it the thumbs up.

380.64.text: So, Barry, get this wrong, you'll be out.

382.92.text: In which Shakespeare play does a character dress up

385.44.text: as Herne the Hunter, complete with stag horns?

395.92.text: It's not A Midsummer Night's Dream.

398.56.text: And I can't recall it in Twelfth Night.

401.04.text: I think it's The Merry Wives of Windsor.

404.48.text: it is that rather obscure play, The Merry Wives of Windsor.

407.40.text: So, well done, three points each. Two learned people here.

412.48.text: It gets a bit harder now, Kay,

414.24.text: it goes to Sudden Death, I don't give you alternatives.

417.28.text: In the print by Hokusai, known as The Great Wave,

420.76.text: which snow-capped mountain is in the background?

426.40.text: It is indeed Mount Fuji, well done.

428.88.text: He did lots of them, didn't he? Lots of The Great Wave prints.

433.88.text: What is the English title of Van Gogh's painting Sternennacht,

437.88.text: which depicts a night-time view from his hospital window?

442.24.text: I think this must be Starry Night.

446.72.text: Sudden Death, Kay, back to you.

448.44.text: Rebecca and Lady Rowena are central characters

455.04.text: Ivanhoe is right, well done. Barry.

458.72.text: In the novel To Kill A Mockingbird,

461.04.text: the character of Dill is based on which US author born in 1924?

471.04.text: Harper Lee was very good friends with Truman Capote.

474.44.text: So I'm going to say Truman Capote.

476.84.text: Truman Capote is correct, Barry, well done.

479.64.text: Kay, who wrote the novels, The Maid Of Buttermere,

482.60.text: A Time To Dance, and The Soldier's Return?

485.96.text: I think that was Melvyn Bragg.

490.72.text: Red, a play by John Logan, which premiered in London in 2009,

497.48.text: and work of which 20th-century abstract expressionist artist?

502.36.text: I don't know the play, but I think I'll have a shot at Mark Rothko.

508.88.text: Kay, which Italian Renaissance artist spent his last years

512.84.text: in France as a painter, architect and engineer to King Francis I?

521.64.text: I would need a first name and a last name

524.28.text: but it's wrong anyway. Leonardo da Vinci.

529.24.text: The artist Maurice Utrillo was born in which country?

533.56.text: His mother was Suzanne Valadon and he was born in France.

538.04.text: How do you know his mother's name, for Pete's sake?

540.32.text:
- She also is a famous artist. 
- OK.

542.92.text: France is right. What a round! Kay, really, toe-to-toe, that was.

548.40.text: Barry's taken it, though, just at the end there,

550.80.text: and will be in the final.

552.04.text: Please both of you return to us and we will play on.

556.00.text: Bad luck, Kay, on that round, cos you...

558.52.text: I won't say you deserved it, but my goodness,

560.68.text:
- we don't see many players as good as you are. 
- No, indeed.

563.32.text: Anyway, if it's going to be like that all the way through,

565.88.text: Eggheads, you've got a battle on here.

567.56.text: But then you are fighting The Old Contemptibles.

571.20.text: They've lost a brain, the Eggheads have not lost one yet.

574.12.text: The next subject for you is Science.

581.32.text:
- David. 
- David? OK, David is going to do Science. Against which Egghead?

589.92.text: doesn't look as if he's spent much time in a laboratory.

592.60.text: Certainly not. No, I've been studied.

594.64.text: I was going to say, may be.

596.32.text: So, David from The Old Contemptibles plays CJ from the Eggheads

599.36.text: on Science and just to make sure there's no conferring,

601.84.text: please go to our Question Room.

605.00.text: So, good luck here, David, on Science. Against the great CJ.

609.28.text:
- Would you like to go first or second? 
- I'll go first, please.

616.96.text: Here we go, for what does the letter R stand in the abbreviation

620.88.text: MRSA, the bacterium that is often referred to as a superbug?

638.32.text: CJ, daddy-longlegs is a common name in the UK

646.52.text: I think a daddy-longlegs is a crane fly.

649.60.text: Crane fly is correct, so first point to CJ.

652.40.text: David, try and beat him back now.

654.52.text: The American inventor Thomas Edison was named the Wizard of where...?

665.52.text: Yes, it is indeed, well done. Menlo Park.

670.16.text: What name, translating loosely from Latin as "two long teeth",

674.36.text: is given to a large, extinct carnivore that had

677.68.text: a distinctive sail-like crest down the length of its back?

687.04.text: It's not the Diplodocus, it's not Diceratops, it is Dimetrodon.

692.44.text: although we don't seem to have heard of it very much.

694.84.text: It's famous cos it has the big...

696.92.text: Long tail, very low creature, walked on all fours,

700.24.text: big sail on its back which was used to regulate heat.

703.00.text:
- You obviously know a lot about dinosaurs. 
- Yep.

707.56.text: Got two out of two, CJ, inconveniently for us.

710.96.text: Which penguin, one of the most southerly-breeding species,

714.36.text: is characterised by a small ring of white feathers surrounding each eye?

724.76.text: I think it's in the Adelie penguin.

727.52.text: Yeah, it is the Adelie penguin.

729.32.text: Have you got some penguin experience?

735.24.text: OK, CJ, all the same, if you get this right, the round is yours.

738.80.text: Cos David got the first one wrong.

740.84.text: The axis of which planet in our solar system lies almost parallel

747.08.text: which means that it spins while appearing to lie on its side?

757.96.text: weird things that happen in the solar system.

761.20.text: Venus, for example, its day is longer than its year,

764.72.text: but I think the one with the parallel axis is Uranus.

769.44.text: Uranus is the right answer. David, I'm sorry, you just couldn't

772.92.text: get any daylight in there with CJ, could you?

775.60.text: So you've been knocked out, I'm afraid.

777.60.text: The Eggheads can do that, they are playing rather well.

780.12.text: Come back to us, please, and we will play on.

784.64.text: OK, Alistair, The Old Contemptibles have lost a couple of brains

789.56.text: That's it, or trench foot. One or the other.

794.08.text: OK, well, the Eggheads have not lost any,

795.96.text: but at some point they are going down, there's no doubt.

798.96.text: So, let's see if a crack opens up. The next subject is Music.

805.68.text: I think, yes... Do you want to do that?

809.28.text: OK, the skipper goes in. Alistair, against which Eggheads?

812.76.text: We can see who we've got here, Chris and Judith and Pat.

816.12.text: Right, what do you think, then?

817.72.text: Of those three, I think Chris.

819.44.text: You think Chris, do you? Are we agreed?

823.60.text:
- Yeah? 
- On the basis that it may be more recent music.

827.48.text: We've not have any classical questions for ages,

830.68.text: so there ought to be some classical questions coming out.

833.56.text:
- We had a question about a bassoon. 
- Bassoon? 
- Yes.

837.08.text: You said that in the manner of Lady...

840.52.text:
- AS LADY BRACKNELL: 
- A handbag? 
- LAUGHTER

843.00.text: So Alistair from The Old Contemptibles,

844.80.text:
- versus Chris "The Bassoon" from the Eggheads. 
- "Buffoon" to you!

847.84.text: And please go to the Question Room now.

851.36.text: OK, Alistair, would you like to go first or second?

860.48.text: OK, so, Chris, this is your question.

863.08.text: Which song, a UK number-one hit for Wiz Khalifa

866.40.text: and Charlie Puth in 2015 features on the soundtrack

869.20.text: of the film Fast And Furious 7?

878.00.text: Well, going by the general milieu of Fast And Furious,

882.12.text: I'd say it would have to be Bad Blood.

885.24.text: No, that's the Taylor Swift one. See You Again is the answer.

892.48.text: It's quite good, you've not even answered a question yet,

896.04.text: When describing vinyl records, LP usually stands for what?

903.52.text: Well, I think it's to do with how long the record lasts

907.84.text: as opposed to a single, so I would go for long-playing.

914.40.text: Chris, which of these classical composers

916.72.text: lived for the shortest length of time?

928.08.text: So it has to be Franz Schubert.

931.48.text: There we are - that's your classical question,

933.88.text:
- you said they hadn't been coming up. 
- Well, it has now. 
- It has now.

936.88.text:
- All we need now is a rap question and you'll be happy. 
- Yes, indeed.

942.80.text: OK, Alistair, where was Hozier, best-known for his hit single

952.88.text: Nothing springs to mind, I think I'll go for Scotland.

960.32.text: What have we got here? One point each. Chris, your question.

963.04.text: Curtis Jackson is the real name of which American rapper?

967.12.text: Just when I... hoped for a rap question.

976.92.text: Eggheads, let's just see that again in slow motion, please.

980.84.text: Let's do the despair, let's see it.

985.00.text: No, it's 50 Cent, Chris. So you got that wrong.

989.80.text: if you get this right, you're in the final round.

992.16.text: Words written by the poet James Thomson

994.48.text: are used for the lyrics of which patriotic song?

1004.24.text: Land Of Hope And Glory is Thomas Alan, I think.

1008.80.text: Out of the other two, I'd go for Rule Britannia.

1011.80.text: Rule Britannia is the right answer, well done, Alistair,

1014.28.text: maybe turning it around for your team, good stuff.

1018.24.text: Lot of money we're playing for here.

1020.60.text: Come back to us and we'll see what happens in the next round.

1025.12.text: So a bit of movement back for The Old Contemptibles.

1027.56.text: They have lost two but the Eggheads have now lost one brain,

1036.24.text:
- Right... Shall I...? 
- If you volunteer. 
- Yep.

1040.88.text: Jeremy, another Jeremy who loves his Politics, I feel at home.

1044.04.text:
- Against which Egghead? 
- Well, what do we think?

1049.56.text:
- Yeah, OK, we'll do that, then. Yeah. 
- Judith.

1052.36.text: OK. Jeremy from The Old Contemptibles

1056.20.text: On Politics. To ensure there's no conferring,

1058.36.text: please go to the Question Room.

1061.36.text: I think you're quite good on Politics, Judith,

1063.84.text:
- shall I tell you why? 
- Yes, cos I beat Edwina Currie.

1068.48.text: Yes, we had a celeb team and Edwina Currie did Politics

1072.40.text: and chose me, and I beat her.

1074.28.text: You may not remember, we had a guy on who was the highest scorer

1077.44.text: on Fifteen To One or something like that.

1079.28.text: He came on and you beat him on Politics..

1082.76.text: So, we're into very strong Judith territory now.

1086.16.text: But I guess you like your Politics as well, as you're called Jeremy.

1089.32.text:
- That's right, Jeremy, yes. 
- Yeah, cos I love mine.

1092.00.text: So would you like to go first or second?...

1094.12.text: I think I'll go first, please.

1098.80.text: So, here we go, good luck, Jeremy. And your question is...

1102.04.text: Which woman, who became famous as a model,

1104.52.text: did the French president Nikolas Sarkozy marry in 2008?

1114.04.text: Right, well, I think I know this one. Which is good.

1117.36.text: I think that is Carla Bruni.

1119.20.text: It is Carla Bruni, well done.

1123.36.text: Who became Chancellor of the Exchequer in 2010?

1132.64.text: Well, I think it's George Osborne.

1134.76.text: George Osborne is the right answer.

1137.20.text: Back to you, Jeremy. In which year did Ceylon,

1141.76.text: appoint the world's first female prime minister?

1149.60.text: Right, I think that was Mrs Bandaranaike, I think that was 1960.

1153.20.text: Yes, it was 1960. I'm sensing you know your stuff.

1156.52.text: We've got some quizzers here, haven't we, Eggs?

1162.80.text: was Martin Luther King Jr assassinated in 1968?

1170.80.text: Well, I think it was Memphis.

1177.08.text: Who was the only president of the USA in the 20th century

1187.52.text: Right, well, I think I know the answer.

1192.60.text: I'm fairly sure it wasn't Dwight Eisenhower, I think

1196.40.text: Yes, indeed, it was before he married Nancy, I guess.

1199.44.text:
- I can't remember who it was. Who was it? 
- Jane Wyman.

1204.48.text: Yeah, good, Jeremy, Ronald Reagan is right. Three out of three.

1209.92.text: Which of these women was nicknamed the Iron Butterfly?

1218.32.text: Well, Margaret Thatcher is the Iron Lady, the Iron Butterfly...

1222.00.text: I think it was Imelda Marcos.

1226.76.text: Well done, Judith. And well done, Jeremy,

1229.36.text: three out of three for you both.

1231.04.text: Good round so far, we go to Sudden Death, Jeremy.

1233.24.text: It gets a bit harder, as you know, I don't give you alternatives.

1237.64.text: for what do both of the letter O's stand in the acronym OMOV?

1247.32.text:
- As in one member, one vote? 
- Yes.

1252.40.text: What is the name of the guerrilla organisation

1254.60.text: that overthrew the Somoza ruling dynasty in Nicaragua in 1979?

1263.72.text: One of them's called the Shining Path.

1266.24.text: In one of those South American countries.

1268.76.text: But I don't think it's that one.

1273.36.text: I'm going to have to say the Shining Path.

1280.16.text:
- This was the Sandinistas. 
- That's right, absolutely.

1283.32.text: So you've lost the round to Jeremy. Well done, Jeremy, on Politics.

1286.36.text: I think you've still got some fuel in the tank there, as well,

1288.92.text: you will be in the final round.

1290.92.text: If you both return to us, we will play the final round for £17,000.

1298.12.text: This is what we have been playing towards.

1300.40.text: It is time for the final round

1301.68.text: which, as always, is General Knowledge.

1303.44.text: But I'm afraid those of you who lost your head-to-heads

1305.84.text: won't be allowed to take part in this round.

1308.36.text: So that is David and Kay from The Old Contemptibles,

1311.72.text: and Judith and Chris from the Eggheads.

1313.84.text: Would you please now leave the studio?

1319.20.text: you're playing to win The Old Contemptibles £17,000.

1322.48.text: On the other side, we've got the Eggheads,

1325.20.text: two Brain Of Britain winners and CJ de Mooi!

1332.72.text: Anyway, all good quizzers, as you know.

1334.80.text: Eggheads, you are playing for something that money can't buy,

1339.28.text: And you are doing so well so far,

1340.76.text: you wanted to keep this streak going.

1342.48.text: As usual, I will ask each team three questions in turn,

1345.40.text: this time the questions are all General Knowledge.

1347.84.text: You are allowed to confer, gentlemen.

1350.36.text: So, Old Contemptibles, the question is,

1353.12.text: are your three brains able to destroy these three over here?

1357.04.text: In a gentle and polite way.

1358.48.text: OK, Jimmy, I'll ask you, would you like to go first or second?

1362.44.text: I think we'll go first, Jeremy.

1368.24.text: Here we go, I'm feeling like this is a contest we've got here,

1376.12.text: Which football team won the 2014/15 Premier League?

1385.52.text:
- ALL: Chelsea, wasn't it? 
- Definitely. 
- Yes, definitely.

1395.60.text: Which of these is a book by Nick Hornby?

1405.04.text:
- Who was Man And Boy, was that Tony Parsons? 
- Yeah, I think so.

1414.44.text: High Fidelity is quite right. it's tricky that,

1417.12.text: Because he did write About A Boy. But not Man And Boy.

1422.96.text: Who plays the title role in

1433.92.text:
- I have no idea on this. 
- No, I've not seen it.

1440.60.text: There's two Lilys and one Emilia,

1442.32.text: I think it's probably going to be a Lily...

1444.64.text: Mm... Well, that's as good an argument as anything...

1447.64.text:
- But which Lily? 
- Shall we go for Lily Collins?

1450.64.text:
- Lily Collins. 
- It's a one-in-three chance, yes, go for that,

1455.88.text: We aren't sure, Jeremy. Obviously, two Lilys, one Emilia.

1462.88.text: Yeah, it is one of the two Lilys, but you went for the wrong one,

1468.52.text: She plays Rose in Downton Abbey.

1470.84.text: By the way. Eggheads, to take the lead...

1474.28.text: South Africa is bordered by how many countries?

1481.16.text:
- I think it's four. 
- It's got to be, cos you've got...

1490.08.text: You've only got one of those two, one's internal.

1492.76.text: But why are you excluding an internal border?

1496.36.text:
- Oh, true... 
- It's a border with... 
- It's a border. 
- ..customs posts.

1500.92.text: It has a border with Lesotho...

1505.08.text: Can you just repeat the question, please?

1507.08.text: South Africa is bordered by how many countries?

1509.84.text: All right, so you've got to include it...

1516.76.text: That's five, what's the sixth? What are we missing?

1519.48.text: Does Zimbabwe come all the way down?

1521.88.text: I think it does...because I think there's been a big fuss

1525.44.text:
- about Zimbabweans coming over... 
- Well, I thought it did,

1528.16.text: cos I've flown from...Jo'burg to Harare...

1532.64.text:
- And it was a very short flight. 
- So you think that makes it six?

1536.60.text:
- That makes it six. 
- OK, we'll go that way.

1538.80.text: We're going to go for six, Jeremy.

1540.68.text: A fascinating discussion because I can see if Lesotho and Swaziland

1544.00.text: are inside South Africa, does that count as being bordered by...?

1547.00.text: But it does, for our purposes, OK, so you're right to include them.

1549.84.text: Also right to include Zimbabwe, cos there is a big issue

1552.60.text: in South Africa with Zimbabweans floating over the border. Bang on.

1555.84.text:
- Well done. I could see how that could go wrong. 
- That was teamwork.

1559.16.text: That could go wrong, cos you could say well, Lesotho,

1562.24.text: Swaziland, they are not running outside the border.

1565.08.text: But, anyway, you got it right. Six.

1569.00.text: So, you must get this one right.

1570.92.text: Who won an Academy Award for best actor

1573.56.text: for his role as a recovering alcoholic/country music singer

1590.92.text: I don't think it's Gene Hackman.

1592.52.text: If I had to guess, I'd say Robert Duvall,

1596.40.text: Well, I think it's Jason Robards.

1597.96.text:
- Are you quite sure on that? 
- Jason Robards Jnr, isn't it?

1601.84.text:
- Jason Robards Jnr, I don't really know a lot about. 
- Yeah.

1606.08.text: I'm pretty sure Robert Duvall has won an Oscar.

1608.68.text: I would go for... If I had to choose, I would go

1611.56.text: for Robert Duvall, but I'm not sure.

1613.60.text: Well, we'll go with that consensus, but I think it's Jason Robards...

1620.92.text:
- So, we're going for Robert Duvall, then? 
- OK, we'll go for that.

1625.88.text: Duvall is your answer. Jimmy, well done, you gave way, which was good.

1629.52.text:
- Cos it is Robert Duvall. 
- Brilliant, brilliant.

1632.24.text:
- That can be painful... 
- I always do as I'm told.

1635.08.text: Yeah, you did well to give way there.

1637.28.text: OK, so, Eggheads still have it in their hands if they win this.

1641.00.text: What was the name of the giant panda

1643.28.text: that was a key attraction at London Zoo from 1958 to 1972?

1653.08.text:
- It was Chi Chi... 
- Chi Chi was the big panda, yeah.

1655.56.text:
- I think Tian Tian is in Edinburgh, isn't it? 
- Yeah.

1658.36.text:
- Chi Chi was at London Zoo. 
- OK...

1661.32.text: We're going to go for Chi Chi.

1663.68.text:
- Chi Chi, do you know this one, guys? 
- Yes, Chi Chi is right.

1669.84.text: you've pulled it off again, Eggheads, well done.

1672.36.text: We say congratulations, you have won.

1682.04.text: In distant memory, what was the one you got wrong there?

1684.72.text:
- Cinderella. 
- That's hard,... 
- Lily James and Lily Collins.

1688.88.text: Yes, well, commiserations to The Old Contemptibles,

1691.56.text: great team story, by the way, Jimmy, thank you so much for that.

1696.16.text: The Eggheads have done what comes naturally to them, though.

1700.64.text: It does mean the Challengers don't go home with the £17,000,

1704.12.text: so we'll add another 1,000 and play for that next time.

1707.80.text: Eggheads, well done. I'm going to say, hands on the table here,

1715.92.text: to see if a new team of Challengers can defeat them.

1718.20.text: £18,000 says they can't. Till then, goodbye.
